bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 8, 1938

div1.p: [Hench] discusses the future clinic visit of Mr. and Mrs. Swartz. He regrets that Lord Dawson is unable to be the speaker.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 8, 1938
div1.p:
We shall be delighted to have Mr. and Mrs. Swartz come here for a
general examination. I have phoned the Kahler for a medium priced room with
twin beds and bath beginning Tuesday morning, February 22. I have made a
definite appointment at the Clinic for them and would be glad if they would
phone me upon their arrival at the hotel. They can phone me at home, and if
I am not at home, phone the Clinic. I shall be glad to meet them and get
them started that morning. I am taking the liberty of writing them a note.
Two days will hurry things considerably, but we can hurry things up by having
them report without breakfast, etc. I am having both of them registered in
Dr. Logan's section, and I also will be on the lookout for them. Since my
own section is devoted to special work I thought it best to have them regis-
tered in a general section although I will want to see that they get along
as fast as possible. It might be best for them to plan to stay three or
four days rather than two.

As far as expense is concerned, that is difficult to say. In confidence,
it costs the Clinic about forty dollars for each patient that comes in the
front door, so that a hundred dollar charge which is the maximum average for
a man of ordinary means to have a very thorough examination doesn't reap very
many proceeds when you realize how many men are apt to see him, how many labora-
tory tests there are, etc., but I am sure that they will be satisfied with the
charge, whatever it is. He doesn't have to worry about paying it all when
he leaves if he doesn't want to. He can pay something down and pay the rest
month by month. Dr. Logan and I will make sure that he is satisfied.

Why can't you come out either with them or preferably before them?
The room is waiting for you at the house unless Mother happens to arrive sooner
than we expect, in which case I will share part of my bed with you, if you
promise not to look over my shoulder at my wife. How about meeting us in New
York as I wrote you?

Sorry to hear that Lord Dawson can't come. Would there be any advantage
in my seeing him? You have my other letter by now. I agree that rather than
have the affair go off half right it would be better to wait and have it go
off the way you want it.
